Fields.DialogueText: The INPF acknowledges your permission. Proceeding slow ahead east-northeast to the rendezvous point.

Fields.MenuText: Aren't you supposed to be in sick bay, Medical Officer?
Do we have anyone for the watch, or are the usual guys down for the count?

Fields.DialogueText: And our sick sailors?
We're press-ganging the galley crew.
Listen, I'll deal with them. You and the salvage team didn't ask for this, and I mean to help you through it.
Right. Part of the job.
This is Contraalmirante Vicente Alvarado. You are cleared to enter the red zone.
@BATTLE
Johnny on the spot.
Given your reputation, I assume you know what you're doing, but... I don't think you know what you signed up for here.
I "signed up for" fixing the holes in our reality. Anything on the way is just part of the job.
My shift ended an hour ago. Should un-end in two.

Fields.MenuText: Something on your mind?

Fields.DialogueText: Still getting their morphine.
Whatever it is, it's made it so they only speak scream when they're awake. Nonsense, mostly. About all we can do is give them a good time.
Hell of a time for a fever. It's not contagious?
Be a downright heroic incubation period if it was.
Even Disease doesn't operate that way.
She's a flashy bitch, thank goodness. Doesn't hide her prognoses.
Well, my orders stand. No one on the ship and no one off until we figure this out or they die.
We're not going to have another Santa Catarina. And we're not losing another salvage team to some harebrained ghost hunt.
You tell Admiral Nash that? And the Brit?
You mean Miriam Vane? I'm not asking her permission. The INPF didn't order us to be her test subjects.
With respect--
Besides, I suppose it'd be boring being the control group all the time.
Well, we're seeing the world. Recruit was honest about that, anyway.

Fields.MenuText: But from the North Sea to the Pacific...

Fields.DialogueText: Morganas gonna Morgana, right?
Right. Nothing to do but wait to die.
Right. Sorry, Captain. But if there's a pattern, why should it respect our borders? Or patrols?
Wouldn't need patrols if it did.
I just wish we knew what we were patrolling for.
Last distress signal of SS Athenia?
What?

Fields.MenuText: That bad? I guess I should have expected it.

Fields.DialogueText: I still don't understand the skeleton crew regulation.

Fields.MenuText: Well, if Gluttony were a Morgana, they might be able to spot us some supplies.

Fields.DialogueText: Not any of the kind you'd want to eat.
Sounds like you've done some thinking about this.
Who hasn't? There's been a pool on new Morganas since Sloth showed up.
The Mexicans insisted, and I tend to agree. They're not taking any chances with... whatever they found.
Nor should they.
You'd know better than I would. Done for the day?
Panama. The American quarantine.
Think that's where our folks picked up... whatever it is?
I know that's where they picked it up. I try not to think about just how big this problem really could be.
Yeah. Rumor has it they had just enough fuel to drive to their position and keep people there.
The one with tanks.
Well, you're doing all you can.
Trying to.
She woke up and said something about the Pacific. Said they were everywhere, whoever they were.
Then she sank before she could elaborate.
Wait. Have you been listening in on--
It's all over the papers, Captain. You really need to read more.
Apologies, Captain. I--
No, I'm just trying to figure out how to respond some way that isn't classified eight times over.
*ALARM*
There goes my sleep.
First casualty of combat. At least Mexico's got our backs.
Dare I ask who's favored?
Well, with her and Avarice, the smart betting's on another of the seven deadlies. Pride, maybe. Lust... well, I guess there's Sin for that.
Say, you wouldn't like to--
I most certainly would not. Don't you have something better to do?

Fields.MenuText: Why did she send the roach along, again?

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, Ube Yammy insisted. She thinks something's up here, and I tend to agree with her.
Who the hell is Ube Yammy?
Another one of Recruit's roaches. She took a trip to Honolulu and loved the island flavors.
Another Belle breakdown. Brilliant.
So most everyone where I come from says the Germans did Athenia. Germany says the Brits did it to themselves.
Uh-huh.
What nobody has an explanation for is the last broadcast.
Oh, here we go.
Oh, you've listened to it!
Of course I haven't. Nobody has.
But the transcripts--
There are no transcripts. Two destroyers, two cargo ships, and a goddamn yacht got bits and pieces of her ranting and raving.
The rest is static. Static and...
Classified?
You have to know what something is to classify it.
Until then it's--
A fever dream.
Yeah. Yeah, that's about the size of it.
On the subject of dreams--
Of course. Get some rest. I was about to shoo you away anyway. Captain business.
Aye-aye. It's just...
Classified, whatever it is.
Point taken.
Dreams just... just never used to mean anything.
Ain't that the truth.
Running your men ragged out there.

Fields.MenuText: Let's cut to the chase.
Where's the fight?
Sorry for the delay. We had to take on fresh crew in Panama City.

Fields.DialogueText: Admiral. Glad you could make it.
Capitán. Welcome to the Revillagigedos.
Sí. We have little enough time as it is.
Somewhere in this patch of sea. My only regret is that it isn't further from the mainland.
You'll forgive our insistence. You got there just in time for the quarantine.
And yet we weren't turned away from the red zone.
Within our extraordinary regulations?
You'll find that the galley hasn't suffered for it, at least.

Fields.MenuText: We're putting minimal hands through maximum paces.
Yes. I still don't see what this is all about.

Fields.DialogueText: In any event. If the Morganas have taught us anything, it's that if there's a problem, we'd prefer to deal with it all at once.
Now, you've just come from Panama.
Under armed escort. Not that we don't appreciate it in this day and age. We were working on a reduced headcount before some joker brought whatever-it-is aboard.
You're a special case, Capitán. An exception had to be made.
You think the Morganas have something to do with the sickness?
I'm certain, Capitán. I've read the reports out of the Baltic. Those planes are just the beginning.
Further than... what is it, four hundred kilometers?
It's that bad.
You know as well as I do what the Morganas are doing to widen the hole they've torn between our world and theirs.
Better. I saw what came through back in November. While we were fighting for our lives, the Morganas were rolling out the red carpet for Sloth.
Until they didn't. You saw how they treated her in the Siegmund incident.
Of course I did. Morgana infighting is nothing new. They're sharks snapping for the next big bite.
I wish they were as savage as you believe.
What do you mean?
Secretary Castro's been over the reports too. He ordered this exclusion zone put in place before the Panama quarantine.
You see, we have reason to believe that the first victim of this sickness was not a human. It was a Morgana.
I thought Morganas couldn't get sick. Hell, they've got--
Disease, yes. In fact it was she who we found beached on Roca Partida.
The ship was reported wedged upon the rocks, and the Morgana herself was clinging to the one on the port side.
She was clearly incapable of sailing under her own power. But she was able to radio us.
And you listened to her?
We've been taken in by Morganas playing dead before. This wasn't that.
"Kill me," she said.
Well. Broken clocks.
We used to think the Morganas were groggy, confused, lashing out in any direction as they emerged blinking into the light.
Some of them are, to be sure. But others are wide awake. And for every one in our world with one foot still in theirs, there is one in theirs plotting her arrival in ours.
By any means necessary.
... Admiral. I'll admit that whether or not this sounds nuts is moot at this stage. We've got experience with those bug planes in the Weddell Sea.
We're still nailing down just how those planes are summoned and what they might herald. But we're going to need more to go on than a Morgana who had an off day.
I thought you'd never ask. But it'll have to wait.
It's not just the alarm.
No.
Well, what are we waiting for?
Someone else to have another off day.
I hate waiting.
So do they. Whoever they are.
@BATTLE
Delayed. We can't keep slapping down her points of ingress forever.
So you thwarted a new Morgana from using Disease as... what? A beacon? A portal?
We obliged, of course.
Observation suggested the same symptoms as Panama, as your people - fatigue, delirium, occasional convulsions.

Fields.MenuText: Even if you hadn't, it would be a safe assumption. It's unlike anything we've seen.
I don't disagree, but I still think the INPF liaison who wrote them is reading too much into this.

Fields.DialogueText: The Frenchman? Commandant Alexis? Why, Capitán, he was there for Sloth's awakening. We owe our entire operation to his firsthand experience, in a way.
Thanks to his parsing of Morgana radio traffic dating back through September, we were able to pinpoint the next emergence zone.
For a given value of "pinpoint."
Exhaustive work nonetheless.
Yes. And we've all heard of Santa Catarina by now.
Hell of a time to finally take that Pacific cruise.
One of these days you'll have to come see these islands when they're not under quarantine. The diving is excellent.

Fields.MenuText: Assuming the Morganas haven't eaten the oysters.
So I keep hearing from the crew.
I believe the Morganas interrupted you while you were making a point.

Fields.DialogueText: Until Gluttony appears, I doubt we're in any danger.
You haven't seriously gotten in on that betting pool nonsense.
Unbecoming of my station. But it's always fun to speculate.
You'll have to tell me what that's like.
Well, I was in the camp of people who thought Sloth might look like an actual sloth. Even sketched out what that might look like, if you're interested.
I'll pass, thank you. But you might have a future in art.
I had a past in art, until my father told me very firmly to get my head out of the clouds.
I guess I have him to thank for our professional relationship.
Broken clocks, as they say.
Yes. It's something I wish Vane had brought you up to speed on.
What didn't she tell me?
A shame it's so dangerous of late.

Fields.MenuText: Tell that to some of my people. I can't keep them out of the water.

Fields.DialogueText: I believe the Morganas interrupted you while you were making a point.

Fields.MenuText: Not to mention irresponsible.

Fields.DialogueText: We'd come across Disease on a tip from a certain Belle.
Some people look at pirates and think treasure.
Some of the ones in sick bay had started to figure out where certain Morganas wrecked in certain ports. I'd managed to keep ahead of any salvage adventures when we put in... that I know of.
Elaborate.
Morgana salvage is... it's...
You've seen what they're capable of, Admiral. None of their materiel belongs in human hands.
All it takes is one human to decide otherwise.
One problem solved another.
So it would seem.
Are you still in contact with her?
Yes and no.
It's always something with Belles.
Her name is Orizaba. She's a yacht with a... colorful history, of late.
Small ship... Unusual, but not unheard of. Italy's got Amerigo Vespucci, the States have Lanikai...
There's the rub, Capitán. They're awake.
She's... stuck.
What do you mean stuck? She's either awake or she isn't.
Her awakening was... well, some of the Americans have taken to calling it a Mae West.
A what now?
Multiple Awakening Event With Extraordinary Shipgirl Traits.
I... hell. Fine. How extraordinary is "extraordinary" these days?
Orizaba was in the north Atlantic until recently, in the possession of a Swede. At that time she was named Southern Cross.
Southern Cross? Wait, I know that name... no. You can't be serious. Not the same Southern Cross that rescued survivors from--
SS Athenia. She was a Belle too... for about fourteen hours.
Right. Athenia awoke at the moment she was hit.
Imagine opening a door, getting a shotgun blast in the face, and clinging to life and to the doorframe, mumbling for help.
That's Vane's working theory, anyway.
So you're telling me Athenia's broadcast woke up Southern Cross... Orizaba... and she got something out of all that nonsense?
Athenia stepped through a hole of her own - one that's not meant to stay open for long.
Whatever was behind her words, it hit Orizaba hard. She's been in some sort of coma for four months.
So the tip was her talking in her sleep?
We've monitored her radio around the clock since she was turned over to us. All anyone's ever been able to make out is the coordinates of the center of the Revillagigedos...
And the words "She's coming."
So for four months you've been patrolling this stretch of sea, waiting for something more horrible than usual to appear.
I did.
... Admiral. You mentioned other points of ingress.
I don't suppose you can tell me how you dealt with them.
You're an exception, Capitán. I can't tell you what to do with your sickened crew, any more than I can tell the Americans what to do in Panama.
Suppose you could.
We've seen that fever in your sick bay before. Our first sailor who got it died within the week. What *actually* killed him... well.
If it were up to me, I'd put that whole contingent in a lifeboat and shell it until that horrible buzzing sound stopped.

Fields.MenuText: Well, I can't give up on my crew. We've got them under lock and key and constant watch.

Fields.DialogueText: Whoever this Morgana is, Capitán... she's counting on that. And she's listening.
@BATTLE
It's not a disease. It's a parasite.
Did you say "buzzing?"

Fields.MenuText: You destroyed whatever it was, I trust.

Fields.DialogueText: This thing emerged after killing several of the parasites. We have her under armed guard at all times.
No need for the guards. I recognize one of Recruit's little friends any day.
Then she'll be able to talk to our Belles and provide some critical information.
See to it you find out sooner than later. This new Morgana is staying close to her children.
We destroyed whatever we could, but as it turned out, there was something else helping us...
*ALARM*
Who was on watch? Where's the--
Captain!
Taylor! Why the hell aren't you at your station?
Belle's orders, Captain! Sick bay's sealed. Nobody but her in or out!
What the hell is she playing at?
*BZZZZZZZ*
What the hell is that noise?
Is that any way to greet a guest?
Code 21. I thought so.
This is the First Captain of the Neutrality Fleet, speaking on behalf of the League of Nations. Identify yourself at once!
Your kind once called me Infestation.
So like you humans, to hate in others what you deny in yourselves.
What do you think you know about us?
Wouldn't you like to know?
We're going to need a fifty-five-caliber flyswatter.
All of them... they're all...
So this is what the Belle was dealing with. While we were slapping down those bugs... those planes... out there...
They were hatching in here.

Fields.MenuText: We're lucky we weren't all killed.
This is worse than the mist. At least that you can see coming.
Any survivors?

Fields.DialogueText: I don't know what we could have done, Captain. Short of some penicillin and citronella cocktail.
Taylor is going to be *so* smug.
Aye-aye.
*STATIC*
The Belle was on top of it. You... may wish to talk to her here in the next little while.
Takizawa bolted when he saw the first one rupture.

Fields.MenuText: Good instinct. I don't know what we would have done without the Belle.
"Rupture?"

Fields.DialogueText: Our feast has only begun.
Ensign Nash... well, his chest cavity was--
Stop. I'll ask when I write up the after action report.
(Assuming I don't decide to forget.)
... Clean up. Then sleep it off. That's about all we can do.
It's bad enough fighting Morganas outside the ship. Inside... I can only imagine.
You're lucky.
He's one of our best, too. The chief barely even curses at him.
How's he handling the cleanup?
With fire and booze.
You made it.
Just what we needed. Now they have another carrier.
Well, the exclusion zone is moot now. While we're on the subject--
You're right.

Fields.MenuText: Don't start, Admiral. I know what you're going to say.

Fields.DialogueText: If she hadn't awakened here, she would have done it in Panama. The last thing we need is something like her near the canal.
What?
Think about it, Capitán. Disease was the first we know of.
Who knows where else Infestation has been spawning her... her aircraft?
Panama. The Baltic. Antarctica.
And God only knows where else and for how long.
If anything, she succeeded in locking our firepower down in the middle of nowhere before she even arrived.
I think I speak for us both when I say we got lucky with Sloth. Infestation was watching. Waiting. After her... who knows?
I know someone who might. Infestation isn't the only one who's been peeking through the curtains.
Orizaba. She asked for you.
Who? Who could possibly--
By name.
Well. Who am I to question a potential advantage?
Whatever it is, Capitán, she seems confident.
As confident as one can be in a coma, anyway.
Does Vane know about this?
For once, I think you've beaten her to the punch. They ought to make a medal for that.
We'll be waiting, Capitán. Think it over.
My children call to me, and I answer.

Fields.MenuText: We caught one of those planes. One. It's sealed in the brig.

Fields.DialogueText: Think you'll find a use for it?
Assuming it knows better.
But I'd trade it in a heartbeat for my crew.
@BATTLE
Let her go, Captain. The Belle's finally letting us below.
How bad is it?
That compass Santa Catarina found... it wasn't a beacon. The planes aren't being *called* here. They're being *incubated.*
I don't know. A new gremlin appeared?
Save the R&D jokes for-
